raw:
Retrieved from http://vegweb.com/community/stroller-derby/feeding-1-yr-old?qt-sign_in_sign_up_block=1
Text:
You are here

Feeding a 1 yr old?

I know  some of you have 1 yr olds on here, so I am curious as to what you feed your baby?

when merrick was a yr old i fed him mac and cheese casserole with different cut up veggies and a little meat (when he would want to eat meat) in it, spicy ramen noodles with different veggies, crackers, chips, pretzels, if i left the fridge door open then he would get a apple and eat the whole thing. ;D  lol, the gerber graduates corn in the pouch is actually good to much on urself, dunno about the other stuff they have like that.


When my son was 1 (he's 2.5 now) he was still breastfeeding so food was really still being introduced at that point, it was more about him learning how to feed himself, since he had another source of nutrition. I never fed him baby food.
He ate grapes (always cut them in half!) whole grain cereals, frozen peas (which he still loves!) bread....some whole grain crackers... yep... that's pretty much it!
Toddlers will eat what they need to eat and their nutrition should be measured weekly, not daily. For example if they eat fruit all day Monday that's fine, as long as they eat other things during the rest of the week. And they will. As long as you don't feed them refined foods (IE sugar!) they will not get the refined foods addiction that causes them to shun other nutritious foods.
Also don't forget, peas for breakfast is OK! great even! and pancakes for dinner, that's okay too!
OH and never give kids juice!!! If you do be sure it 100% juice and water it down by at least half! Don't worry, They don't know what the full strength stuff tastes like! with the lack of fiber in processed juices you're pretty much just giving them sugar water.

Later, my son fell in love with morning star chicken nuggets, which
A) I was not happy about since it was a packaged food and
B) I don't know how this escaped me for so many months but they have egg whites in it!!!!!! GRR... (he's allergic too!!!)
anyway I just adapted Jennifer Mccann's (vegan lunchbox) recipe for baked tofu fish sticks into a "chicken nugget" he loved them from day one! I don't think he even knew the difference from the MS product. I'll post my recipe on vegweb.

and when he turned 2 (until now) he had this apple habit where he'd want from 1-4 apples a day!!! 4 was rare... but on average 2... 
They weren't giving him any kind of tummyache so I just let him have them! He still ate other foods as well and there are worse things than apples and fiber. :) that lasted a few months and he's over it now. weird huh??

hope that helps...


Oh and sorry I have to mention this, but FYI Ramen Noodles have 1500 (PLUS)mg of sodium
Sodium RDA (for the whole day) for a 14 month old is 325-1000mg per day .... eeek... be careful.


when he got ramen it was when i was eating it. that was also when we were with zack and it was  the only thing there. now we hardly eat it b/c i honestly dont like it that much. zack could live off it everyday.


Thanx for the info. I still breastfeed as well. Not as much as I used to but I mix it in between my daughters meals when she wants a snack or to go to sleep. I give her pretty much every veggie and fruit out there in baby food but I want to start giving her fresh fruit and veggies now that she has 8 teeth.


I only used baby food for about the first month, then moved on to little pieces of things that can be easily 'gummed'. Avocado is a good one, banana, steamed pear and carrot. blueberries are great too. Now that she's skilled with those types of things I give her alot of the same food as us, without the nuts or spices. She has whole grain pasta and homemade bread. I also give her seed butters like pumpkin seed and tahini, which she would eat by the spoonful! I won't give her nuts for a long while yet. I also agree with alot of what Jennifer said. I have recently started giving her rice milk (unsweetened). She occasionally has very watered down, not from concentrate, organic apple juice. I am also still breastfeeding her. Of course, water is also an important liquid for her now.
Vive Le Vegan by Dreena Burton has a really useful food introduction chart in the back. It is also full of delicious, simple recipes.

response:
### **Scene Concept: "Toddler Nutrition Research Lab with Live Observation Kitchen"**  

#### **1. Overall Scene Theme and Core Concept**  
A hybrid **research facility and live observational kitchen** designed to study toddler nutrition, feeding behaviors, and food safety. The space blends **scientific rigor** (lab equipment, data tracking) with **real-world domestic simulation** (a fully functional kitchen where meals are prepared and tested with child volunteers).  

**Why multi-agent?**  
- **Collaborative food prep** (some ingredients require multiple handlers due to weight/contamination risks).  
- **Simultaneous monitoring** (one agent tracks child reactions while another logs data).  
- **Emergency response** (e.g., allergen containment, spill cleanup).  

---  

### **2. Spatial Layout & Key Areas**  
1. **Observation Kitchen** – A child-proofed kitchen with transparent walls for behavioral study.  
2. **Nutrition Lab** – Contains analytical equipment (spectrometers, scales) for food composition testing.  
3. **Cold Storage & Prep Zone** – Walk-in fridge, freezer, and sanitization station.  
4. **Control Room** – Monitoring screens, data terminals, and a live feed of the observation kitchen.  
5. **Play/Feeding Area** – Soft-mat zone with high chairs, spill-resistant flooring, and toy distractions.  
6. **Supply Closet** – Overstocked with backup ingredients, cleaning supplies, and emergency kits.  

---  

### **3. Detailed Area-by-Area Inventory**  

#### **A. Observation Kitchen**  
**a. Anchor Furniture & Installations:**  
- **Stainless steel island (2m x 1m, 120kg)** with built-in induction stovetop and retractable child safety barriers.  
- **Glass-walled observation booth** (one-way mirror, microphone arrays).  
- **Commercial-grade high chair (15kg, adjustable straps, crumb-catching tray).**  

**b. Key Interactive & Task-Relevant Objects:**  
- **Blender (5kg, sealed lid, "Caution: Hot Contents" sticker).**  
- **Digital nutrition scale (precision 0.1g, touchscreen calibration needed).**  
- **Locked spice cabinet (requires keycard, contains potential allergens: peanut powder, sesame oil).**  
- **"Sample Plate" set (3 compartments, color-coded: green=veggies, yellow=carbs, red=proteins).**  

**c. Functional Ambient Objects:**  
- **Steel colander (half-full of rinsed blueberries, placed in drying rack).**  
- **Timer (beeping, set to 8 minutes for steaming carrots).**  
- **Spill-containment cart (holds absorbent pads, disinfectant spray).**  

**d. Background & Decorative Objects:**  
- **Faded "Wash Hands" poster (peeling at corners).**  
- **Chalkboard with scribbled meal plan ("Day 3: Avocado mash test").**  
- **Mismatched toddler utensils (silicone spoon with bunny design, bent metal fork).**  
- **Dusty cookbook ("Vive Le Vegan") on a high shelf.**  

---  

#### **B. Nutrition Lab**  
**a. Anchor Furniture & Installations:**  
- **Centrifuge (60kg, requires two people to move, humming softly).**  
- **Fume hood (currently containing a simmering sodium-test solution).**  
- **Wall-mounted spectrometer (display flickering, last calibration date: 2 days ago).**  

**b. Key Interactive & Task-Relevant Objects:**  
- **Microscope with slides (labeled "Sample 7B: Ramen residue").**  
- **Allergen test strips (expiry date in 3 days, stored in a locked drawer).**  
- **Broken autoclave (error light blinking, requires manual override).**  

**c. Functional Ambient Objects:**  
- **Lab notebook (open to a page with scribbled notes: "High sodium in Gerber pouch??").**  
- **Pipette set (one missing, others arranged by volume).**  
- **Refrigerated sample rack (holding toddler saliva swabs).**  

**d. Background & Decorative Objects:**  
- **Coffee-stained safety manual (bookmarked at "Emergency Protocols").**  
- **Decorative periodic table poster (with toddler-friendly cartoon elements).**  
- **Dented stainless steel tray (holds unrelated paperclips and rubber bands).**  

---  

#### **C. Play/Feeding Area**  
**a. Anchor Furniture & Installations:**  
- **Soft foam playmat (2m x 3m, stained with apple juice).**  
- **Adjustable high chairs (one missing a strap, labeled "Out of Service").**  

**b. Key Interactive & Task-Relevant Objects:**  
- **"Forbidden Foods" demo box (locked, contains candy, whole grapes, honey).**  
- **Spill-proof sippy cup (leaking slightly, needs tightening).**  

**c. Functional Ambient Objects:**  
- **Stack of bibs (one embroidered with "Future Food Critic").**  
- **Basket of sensory toys (squishy avocado plushie, rubber broccoli).**  

**d. Background & Decorative Objects:**  
- **Framed toddler artwork ("My First Pancake" in finger paint).**  
- **Overflowing diaper bag (peeking out: half-eaten rice cracker).**  

---  

### **4. Scene Affordances & Embedded Potential**  

#### **Collaborative Transportation Affordances:**  
- **Centrifuge (60kg, bulky shape)** – Requires two agents to lift safely.  
- **Walk-in fridge door (stiff hydraulic hinge, 20kg push force needed)** – One agent holds food tray while another opens.  

#### **Reasoning & Tool-Use Affordances:**  
- **Attribute-based:**  
  - Five **baby food jars** on the shelf:  
    - Only one has a **blue lid, handwritten "NO EGGS" label.**  
    - Distractor: **A decorative blue vase nearby.**  
- **Compound (Tool-Use):**  
  - **Problem:** Autoclave is locked in "error mode."  
  - **Solution:** Keycard is inside **a lab coat pocket (hung in the supply closet).**  

---  

**Final Notes:**  
This environment is **dense with potential tasks**—food prep, hazard containment, data logging, behavioral observation—all while forcing agents to navigate **realistic clutter, distractions, and layered problem-solving.** The **mix of lab precision and domestic chaos** creates a rich sandbox for embodied AI collaboration.
